update.description:
This addresses issue #2430.

The fix is somewhat unpleasant in order to maintain ABI compatibility.

I believe I can backport these fixes to earlier minor versions of Gazebo 7, and we could do patch releases for them. Is that something we would like to do? If so, what's the earliest minor version that I should backport to?
update.title: Fix Joint::SetPosition for HingeJoint, issue 2430

content.raw: Thanks!
content.html: Thanks!

content.raw: I'm not opposed to it, but I think it's a low priority if we want to transition development effort over to `ign-physics`.
content.html: I'm not opposed to it, but I think it's a low priority if we want to transition development effort over to ign-physics.

content.raw: Do you think we should implement any of these approaches in default?
content.html: Do you think we should implement any of these approaches in default?

content.raw:
Pretty much. I don't think we need to add a new virtual function to `ODEJoint`, but it would be preferable to have `ODEHingeJoint` override `SetPosition`, which is already a virtual function.

(Note that adding a new member function override breaks ABI because it modifies the vtable, which is part of the class definition.)
content.html:
Pretty much. I don't think we need to add a new virtual function to ODEJoint, but it would be preferable to have ODEHingeJoint override SetPosition, which is already a virtual function.

(Note that adding a new member function override breaks ABI because it modifies the vtable, which is part of the class definition.)

content.raw: I considered having `ODEHingeJoint` and `BulletHingeJoint` override the `SetPosition` function, but that would modify the vtable of these classes which would break ABI.
content.html: I considered having ODEHingeJoint and BulletHingeJoint override the SetPosition function, but that would modify the vtable of these classes which would break ABI.

content.raw: would it be a virtual function added to `ODEJoint` instead of a private `ODEHingeJoint` function with a `friend` statement?
content.html: would it be a virtual function added to ODEJoint instead of a private ODEHingeJoint function with a friend statement?

content.raw: Just curiosity: What would be the solution if we could break ABI?
content.html: Just curiosity: What would be the solution if we could break ABI?

content.raw:
I specifically designed it to never lose precision. `currentAngle` will march towards the value of `_position` with a step size of `delta`. Once `currentAngle` is anywhere within `delta` of `_position`, it will call line 615 `currentAngle = _position` which will ultimately set them to be exactly the same, down to the bits.

However, there's admittedly the possibility that both `_position` and `currentAngle` could be so large that incrementing by `delta` will no longer affect `currentAngle` because `delta` is so small that it falls out of the scope of the precision of `currentAngle`. That situation would cause it to get stuck in this loop.

I did a quick test, and found that `currentAngle` would need to have a magnitude of approximately `9.97222e+15` or higher for this loop to get stuck. While I think we can rule out the possibility of any user legitimately wanting such a high joint angle, it would be good to sanitize this function so that we don't accidentally get stuck in this loop after being put into a bad state from a mistake that could have occurred elsewhere.

To give a healthy margin, I could put in a check to make sure that `currentAngle` and `_position` both have a magnitude lower than `1e+12`.
content.html:
I specifically designed it to never lose precision. currentAngle will march towards the value of _position with a step size of delta. Once currentAngle is anywhere within delta of _position, it will call line 615 currentAngle = _position which will ultimately set them to be exactly the same, down to the bits.

However, there's admittedly the possibility that both _position and currentAngle could be so large that incrementing by delta will no longer affect currentAngle because delta is so small that it falls out of the scope of the precision of currentAngle. That situation would cause it to get stuck in this loop.

I did a quick test, and found that currentAngle would need to have a magnitude of approximately 9.97222e+15 or higher for this loop to get stuck. While I think we can rule out the possibility of any user legitimately wanting such a high joint angle, it would be good to sanitize this function so that we don't accidentally get stuck in this loop after being put into a bad state from a mistake that could have occurred elsewhere.

To give a healthy margin, I could put in a check to make sure that currentAngle and _position both have a magnitude lower than 1e+12.

content.raw: thanks for the explanation; looks good
content.html: thanks for the explanation; looks good

content.raw: yeah, I don't see a problem with your algorithm, but maybe for very large numbers it would lose enough precision to not work; much bigger than 100 pi or 1000 pi though
content.html: yeah, I don't see a problem with your algorithm, but maybe for very large numbers it would lose enough precision to not work; much bigger than 100 pi or 1000 pi though

content.raw:
Yes, whether or not a value parameter is const does not affect the function signature and therefore does not impact ABI compatibility. In fact, you will get an ODR violation if you try to define both a function `foo(Arg arg)` and a `foo(const Arg arg)`, because they have the same signature within the ABI. Notice how the header declaration of this function has not changed to include a `const`.

This is different from reference parameters, where the const does matter. So `foo(Arg& arg)`, `foo(const Arg& arg)`, and `foo(Arg arg)` all have different function signatures, which means they are different within the ABI.

Edit: ODE --> ODR (One Definition Rule) ....I've been too immersed in ODE lately.
content.html:
Yes, whether or not a value parameter is const does not affect the function signature and therefore does not impact ABI compatibility. In fact, you will get an ODR violation if you try to define both a function foo(Arg arg) and a foo(const Arg arg), because they have the same signature within the ABI. Notice how the header declaration of this function has not changed to include a const.

This is different from reference parameters, where the const does matter. So foo(Arg& arg), foo(const Arg& arg), and foo(Arg arg) all have different function signatures, which means they are different within the ABI.

Edit: ODE --> ODR (One Definition Rule) ....I've been too immersed in ODE lately.

content.raw:
Mathematically, it can't get stuck, because we ultimately set `currentAngle` to equal `_position` exactly. The only place `currentAngle` gets modified is in lines 609-616, where it is always either brought closer to `_position` or set exactly equal to `_position`.

I originally had the ending condition of this while loop be `currentAngle == _position`, and that worked perfectly (and it always should, because of line 615), but I changed it to this because comparing for equality between doubles raises compiler warnings which I didn't want to bother explicitly suppressing.

All that being said, it would still be a good idea to stress test this like you're suggesting, just in case someone comes along and modifies this code in a harmful way in the future.
content.html:
Mathematically, it can't get stuck, because we ultimately set currentAngle to equal _position exactly. The only place currentAngle gets modified is in lines 609-616, where it is always either brought closer to _position or set exactly equal to _position.

I originally had the ending condition of this while loop be currentAngle == _position, and that worked perfectly (and it always should, because of line 615), but I changed it to this because comparing for equality between doubles raises compiler warnings which I didn't want to bother explicitly suppressing.

All that being said, it would still be a good idea to stress test this like you're suggesting, just in case someone comes along and modifies this code in a harmful way in the future.

content.raw: what do you think about adding a test case for very big angles to make sure they don't get stuck in this loop somewhere, like 100*pi or 1000*pi or something? I don't have any reason to think it would get stuck, but it shouldn't hurt
content.html: what do you think about adding a test case for very big angles to make sure they don't get stuck in this loop somewhere, like 100pi or 1000pi or something? I don't have any reason to think it would get stuck, but it shouldn't hurt

content.raw: is it ok to add `const` here?
content.html: is it ok to add const here?

content.raw: `double` -> `dReal` to match the header file
content.html: double -> dReal to match the header file
